I don't want to hear what they are listening to.

Do you listen to audiobooks? What are the benefits, in your opinion, of listening instead of reading? Are there advantages to reading that cannot be gained by listening? Which method do you prefer? Why?

In my opinion, audiobooks are not as convenient as regular books for multiple reasons. First, to use an audiobook, you have to have speakers or headphones and that can be cumbersome to have with you at all times. I know I find it rude when someone in a waiting room or on public transportation is listening to an audiobook or something on their phone without headphones. It is like an invasion of my space. I don't want to hear what they are listening to.

In my opinion, audiobooks are not as convenient as regular books for multiple reasons. First, to use an audiobook, you have to have speakers or headphones and that can be cumbersome to have with you at all times. I know I find it rude when someone in a waiting room or on public transportation is listening to an audiobook or something on their phone without headphones. It is like an invasion of my space. I don't want to hear what they are listening to. 
econd, you have to be able to listen to the book at a certain pace.

First, to use an audiobook, you have to have speakers or headphones and that can be cumbersome to have with you at all times. I know I find it rude when someone in a waiting room or on public transportation is listening to an audiobook or something on their phone without headphones. It is like an invasion of my space. I don't want to hear what they are listening to. 
econd, you have to be able to listen to the book at a certain pace.
 I am a pretty fast reader and I can get through a book pretty fast. With an audiobook, I have to listen to the words only as fast as the speaker is dictating them. Also, I can go back and re-read a page or passage much easier in a regular book than I can with an audiobook. I

Do you listen to audiobooks? What are the benefits, in your opinion, of listening instead of reading? Are there advantages to reading that cannot be gained by listening? Which method do you prefer? Why?

---

In my opinion, audiobooks are not as convenient as regular books for multiple reasons. First, to use an audiobook, you have to have speakers or headphones and that can be cumbersome to have with you at all times. I know I find it rude when someone in a waiting room or on public transportation is listening to an audiobook or something on their phone without headphones. It is like an invasion of my space. I don't want to hear what they are listening to. 
econd, you have to be able to listen to the book at a certain pace.
 I am a pretty fast reader and I can get through a book pretty fast. With an audiobook, I have to listen to the words only as fast as the speaker is dictating them. Also, I can go back and re-read a page or passage much easier in a regular book than I can with an audiobook. I have to rewind and hope I stop at the right point. It's frustrating. Third, I don't like the way audiobooks sound.
 With an audiobook, you

In my opinion, audiobooks are not as convenient as regular books for multiple reasons. First, to use an audiobook, you have to have speakers or headphones and that can be cumbersome to have with you at all times. I know I find it rude when someone in a waiting room or on public transportation is listening to an audiobook or something on their phone without headphones. It is like an invasion of my space. I don't want to hear what they are listening to. 
econd, you have to be able to listen to the book at a certain pace.
 I am a pretty fast reader and I can get through a book pretty fast. With an audiobook, I have to listen to the words only as fast as the speaker is dictating them. Also, I can go back and re-read a page or passage much easier in a regular book than I can with an audiobook. I have to rewind and hope I stop at the right point. It's frustrating. Third, I don't like the way audiobooks sound.
 With an audiobook, you have to hope you like

First, to use an audiobook, you have to have speakers or headphones and that can be cumbersome to have with you at all times. I know I find it rude when someone in a waiting room or on public transportation is listening to an audiobook or something on their phone without headphones. It is like an invasion of my space. In my opinion, audiobooks are not as convenient as regular books for multiple reasons. First, to use an audiobook, you have to have speakers or headphones and that can be cumbersome to have with you at all times. I know I find it rude when someone in a waiting room or on public transportation is listening to an audiobook or something on their phone without headphones. It is like an invasion of my space. I don't want to hear what they are listening to. 
econd, you have to be able to listen to the book at a certain pace.
 I am a pretty fast reader and I can get through a book pretty fast. With an audiobook, I have to listen to the words only as fast as the speaker is dictating them. Also, I can go back and re-read a page or passage much easier in a regular book than I can with an audiobook. I have to rewind and hope I stop at the right point. It's frustrating. Third, I don't like the way audiobooks sound.

Do you listen to audiobooks? What are the benefits, in your opinion, of listening instead of reading? Are there advantages to reading that cannot be gained by listening? Which method do you prefer? Why?

---

In my opinion, audiobooks are not as convenient as regular books for multiple reasons. First, to use an audiobook, you have to have speakers or headphones and that can be cumbersome to have with you at all times. I know I find it rude when someone in a waiting room or on public transportation is listening to an audiobook or something on their phone without headphones. It is like an invasion of my space. I don't want to hear what they are listening to. 
econd, you have to be able to listen to the book at a certain pace.
 I am a pretty fast reader and I can get through a book pretty fast. With an audiobook, I have to listen to the words only as fast as the speaker is dictating them. Also, I can go back and re-read a page or passage much easier in a regular book than I can with an audiobook. I have to rewind and hope I stop at the right point. It's frustrating. Third, I don't like the way audiobooks sound.

I know I find it rude when someone in a waiting room or on public transportation is listening to an audiobook or something on their phone without headphones. It is like an invasion of my space. In my opinion, audiobooks are not as convenient as regular books for multiple reasons. First, to use an audiobook, you have to have speakers or headphones and that can be cumbersome to have with you at all times. I know I find it rude when someone in a waiting room or on public transportation is listening to an audiobook or something on their phone without headphones. It is like an invasion of my space. I don't want to hear what they are listening to. 
econd, you have to be able to listen to the book at a certain pace.
 I am a pretty fast reader and I can get through a book pretty fast. With an audiobook, I have to listen to the words only as fast as the speaker is dictating them. Also, I can go back and re-read a page or passage much easier in a regular book than I can with an audiobook. I have to rewind and hope I stop at the right point. It's frustrating. Third, I don't like the way audiobooks sound.
 With an audiobook, you have to hope you like the sound of the narrators voice. If you do, you are in good shape, if not, it can make for a long and arduous listen. It also is harder, for me at least, to get a good mental image of the scene w

I know I find it rude when someone in a waiting room or on public transportation is listening to an audiobook or something on their phone without headphones. It is like an invasion of my space. I don't want to hear what they are listening to. 
econd, you have to be able to listen to the book at a certain pace.
 I am a pretty fast reader and I can get through a book pretty fast. With an audiobook, I have to listen to the words only as fast as the speaker is dictating them. Also, I can go back and re-read a page or passage much easier in a regular book than I can with an audiobook. I have to rewind and hope I stop at the right point. It's frustrating. Third, I don't like the way audiobooks sound.
 With an audiobook, you have to hope you like the sound of the narrators voice. If you do, you are in good shape, if not, it can make for a long and arduous listen. It also is harder, for me at least, to get a good mental image of the scene while listening to a

 With an audiobook, you have to hope you like the sound of the narrators voice. If you do, you are in good shape, if not, it can make for a long and arduous listen. It also is harder, for me at least, to get a good mental image of the scene while listening to an audiobook. I can see it in my head much easier when I read. 
Finally

First, to use an audiobook, you have to have speakers or headphones and that can be cumbersome to have with you at all times. I know I find it rude when someone in a waiting room or on public transportation is listening to an audiobook or something on their phone without headphones. It is like an invasion of my space. I don't want to hear what they are listening to.

First, to use an audiobook, you have to have speakers or headphones and that can be cumbersome to have with you at all times. I know I find it rude when someone in a waiting room or on public transportation is listening to an audiobook or something on their phone without headphones. It is like an invasion of my space. I don't want to hear what they are listening to. 
econd, you have to be able to listen to the book at a certain pace.
 I am a pretty fast reader and I can get through a book pretty fast. With an audiobook, I have to listen to the words only as fast as the speaker is dictating them. Also, I can go back and re-read a page or passage much easier in a regular book than I can with an audiobook. I have to rewind and hope I stop at the right point. It's frustrating. Third, I don't like the way audiobooks sound.
 With an audiobook, you have to hope you like the sound of the narrators voice. If you do, you are in good shape, if not, it can make for a long and arduous listen. It also is harder, for me at least, to get a good mental image of the scene while listening to an audiobook. I can see it in my head much easier when I read. 
Finally, I can't lend an oudioboo

Is Listening to a Book Just as Good as Reading It?

econd, you have to be able to listen to the book at a certain pace.

I know I find it rude when someone in a waiting room or on public transportation is listening to an audiobook or something on their phone without headphones. It is like an invasion of my space. I don't want to hear what they are listening to. 
econd, you have to be able to listen to the book at a certain pace.
 I am a pretty fast reader and I can get through a book pretty fast. With an audiobook, I have to listen to the words only as fast as the speaker is dictating them. Also, I can go back and re-read a page or passage much easier in a regular book than I can with an audiobook. I have to rewind and hope I stop at the right point. It's frustrating. Third, I don't like the way audiobooks sound.
 With an audiobook, you have to hope you like the sound of the narrators voice. If you do, you are in good shape, if not, it can make for a long and arduous listen. It also is harder, for me at least, to get a good mental image of the scene while listening to an audiobook. I can see it in my head much easier when I read. 
Finally, I can't lend an audiobook to a friend or family member as easily as a regu

Is Listening to a Book Just as Good as Reading It?

Do you listen to audiobooks? What are the benefits, in your opinion, of listening instead of reading? Are there advantages to reading that cannot be gained by listening? Which method do you prefer? Why?

---

In my opinion, audiobooks are not as convenient as regular books for multiple reasons. First, to use an audiobook, you have to have speakers or headphones and that can be cumbersome to have with you at all times. I know I find it rude when someone in a waiting room or on public transportation is listening to an audiobook or something on their phone without headphones. It is like an invasion of my space. I don't want to hear what they are listening to. 
econd, you have to be able to listen to the book at a certain pace.
 I am a pretty fast reader and I can get through a book pretty fast. With an audiobook, I have to listen to the words only as fast as the speaker is dictating them. Also, I can go back and re-read a page or passage much easier in a regular book than I can with an audiobook. I have to rewind and hope I stop at the right point. It's frustrating. Third, I don't like the way audiobooks sound.
 With an audiobook, you have to hope you like the sound of the narrators voice. If you do, you are in good shape, if not, it can make for a long and arduous listen. It also is harder, for me at least, to get a good mental image of the scene while listening to an audiobook. I can see it in my head much easier when I read. 
Finally, I can't lend an audiobook to a friend or family member as easily as a physical

Third, I don't like the way audiobooks sound.
 With an audiobook, you have to hope you like the sound of the narrators voice. If you do, you are in good shape, if not, it can make for a long and arduous listen. It also is harder, for me at least, to get a good mental image of the scene while listening to an audiobook. I can see it in my head much easier when I read. 
Finally, I can't lend an audiobook to a friend or family member as easily as a physical book. I have to lend t

First, to use an audiobook, you have to have speakers or headphones and that can be cumbersome to have with you at all times. I know I find it rude when someone in a waiting room or on public transportation is listening to an audiobook or something on their phone without headphones. It is like an invasion of my space. Finally, I can't lend an audiobook to a friend or family member as easily as a physical book. I have to lend them my phone or tablet,

Is Listening to a Book Just as Good as Reading It?

Do you listen to audiobooks? What are the benefits, in your opinion, of listening instead of reading? Are there advantages to reading that cannot be gained by listening? Which method do you prefer? Why?

---

In my opinion, audiobooks are not as convenient as regular books for multiple reasons. First, to use an audiobook, you have to have speakers or headphones and that can be cumbersome to have with you at all times. I know I find it rude when someone in a waiting room or on public transportation is listening to an audiobook or something on their phone without headphones. It is like an invasion of my space. I don't want to hear what they are listening to. 
econd, you have to be able to listen to the book at a certain pace.
 I am a pretty fast reader and I can get through a book pretty fast. With an audiobook, I have to listen to the words only as fast as the speaker is dictating them. Also, I can go back and re-read a page or passage much easier in a regular book than I can with an audiobook. I have to rewind and hope I stop at the right point. It's frustrating. Third, I don't like the way audiobooks sound.

Is Listening to a Book Just as Good as Reading It?

Do you listen to audiobooks? What are the benefits, in your opinion, of listening instead of reading? Are there advantages to reading that cannot be gained by listening? Which method do you prefer? Why?

---

In my opinion, audiobooks are not as convenient as regular books for multiple reasons. First, to use an audiobook, you have to have speakers or headphones and that can be cumbersome to have with you at all times. I know I find it rude when someone in a waiting room or on public transportation is listening to an audiobook or something on their phone without headphones. It is like an invasion of my space. I don't want to hear what they are listening to. 
econd, you have to be able to listen to the book at a certain pace.
 I am a pretty fast reader and I can get through a book pretty fast. With an audiobook, I have to listen to the words only as fast as the speaker is dictating them. Also, I can go back and re-read a page or passage much easier in a regular book than I can with an audiobook. I have to rewind and hope I stop at the right point. It's frustrating. Third, I don't like the way audiobooks sound.
 With an audiobook, you have to hope you like the sound of the narrators voice. If you do, you are in good shape, if not, it can make for a long and arduous listen. It also is harder, for me at least, to get a good mental image of the scene while listening to an audiobook. I can see it in my head much easier when I read. 
Finally, I can't lend an audiobook to a friend or family member as easily as a physical book. I have to lend them my phone or tablet, and I don't want to do

Also, I can go back and re-read a page or passage much easier in a regular book than I can with an audiobook. I have to rewind and hope I stop at the right point. It's frustrating. Third, I don't like the way audiobooks sound.
 With an audiobook, you have to hope you like the sound of the narrators voice. If you do, you are in good shape, if not, it can make for a long and arduous listen. It also is harder, for me at least, to get a good mental image of the scene while listening to an audiobook. I can see it in my head much easier when I read. 
Finally, I can't lend an audiobook to a friend or family member as easily as a physical book. I have to lend them my phone or tablet, and I don't want to do that. With a physical

Do you listen to audiobooks? What are the benefits, in your opinion, of listening instead of reading? Are there advantages to reading that cannot be gained by listening? Which method do you prefer? Why?

---

In my opinion, audiobooks are not as convenient as regular books for multiple reasons. First, to use an audiobook, you have to have speakers or headphones and that can be cumbersome to have with you at all times. I know I find it rude when someone in a waiting room or on public transportation is listening to an audiobook or something on their phone without headphones. It is like an invasion of my space. I don't want to hear what they are listening to. 
econd, you have to be able to listen to the book at a certain pace.
 I am a pretty fast reader and I can get through a book pretty fast. With an audiobook, I have to listen to the words only as fast as the speaker is dictating them. Also, I can go back and re-read a page or passage much easier in a regular book than I can with an audiobook. I have to rewind and hope I stop at the right point. It's frustrating. Third, I don't like the way audiobooks sound.
 With an audiobook, you have to hope you like the sound of the narrators voice. If you do, you are in good shape, if not, it can make for a long and arduous listen. It also is harder, for me at least, to get a good mental image of the scene while listening to an audiobook. I can see it in my head much easier when I read. 
Finally, I can't lend an audiobook to a friend or family member as easily as a physical book. I have to lend them my phone or tablet, and I don't want to do that. With a physical book. I can just han

I know I find it rude when someone in a waiting room or on public transportation is listening to an audiobook or something on their phone without headphones. It is like an invasion of my space. I don't want to hear what they are listening to. 
econd, you have to be able to listen to the book at a certain pace.
 I am a pretty fast reader and I can get through a book pretty fast. With an audiobook, I have to listen to the words only as fast as the speaker is dictating them. Also, I can go back and re-read a page or passage much easier in a regular book than I can with an audiobook. I have to rewind and hope I stop at the right point. It's frustrating. Third, I don't like the way audiobooks sound.
 With an audiobook, you have to hope you like the sound of the narrators voice. If you do, you are in good shape, if not, it can make for a long and arduous listen. It also is harder, for me at least, to get a good mental image of the scene while listening to an audiobook. I can see it in my head much easier when I read. 
Finally, I can't lend an audiobook to a friend or family member as easily as a physical book. I have to lend them my phone or tablet, and I don't want to do that. With a physical book. I can just hand them the book and the

econd, you have to be able to listen to the book at a certain pace.
 I am a pretty fast reader and I can get through a book pretty fast. With an audiobook, I have to listen to the words only as fast as the speaker is dictating them. Also, I can go back and re-read a page or passage much easier in a regular book than I can with an audiobook. I have to rewind and hope I stop at the right point. It's frustrating. Third, I don't like the way audiobooks sound.
 With an audiobook, you have to hope you like the sound of the narrators voice. If you do, you are in good shape, if not, it can make for a long and arduous listen. It also is harder, for me at least, to get a good mental image of the scene while listening to an audiobook. I can see it in my head much easier when I read. 
Finally, I can't lend an audiobook to a friend or family member as easily as a physical book. I have to lend them my phone or tablet, and I don't want to do that. With a physical book. I can just hand them the book and they can give it back when

I know I find it rude when someone in a waiting room or on public transportation is listening to an audiobook or something on their phone without headphones. It is like an invasion of my space. I don't want to hear what they are listening to. 
econd, you have to be able to listen to the book at a certain pace.
 I am a pretty fast reader and I can get through a book pretty fast. With an audiobook, I have to listen to the words only as fast as the speaker is dictating them. Also, I can go back and re-read a page or passage much easier in a regular book than I can with an audiobook. I have to rewind and hope I stop at the right point. It's frustrating. Third, I don't like the way audiobooks sound.
 With an audiobook, you have to hope you like the sound of the narrators voice. If you do, you are in good shape, if not, it can make for a long and arduous listen. It also is harder, for me at least, to get a good mental image of the scene while listening to an audiobook. I can see it in my head much easier when I read. 
Finally, I can't lend an audiobook to a friend or family member as easily as a physical book. I have to lend them my phone or tablet, and I don't want to do that. With a physical book. I can just hand them the book and they can give it back when they are done. it

Is Listening to a Book Just as Good as Reading It?

Do you listen to audiobooks? What are the benefits, in your opinion, of listening instead of reading? Are there advantages to reading that cannot be gained by listening? Which method do you prefer? Why?

---

In my opinion, audiobooks are not as convenient as regular books for multiple reasons. First, to use an audiobook, you have to have speakers or headphones and that can be cumbersome to have with you at all times. I know I find it rude when someone in a waiting room or on public transportation is listening to an audiobook or something on their phone without headphones. It is like an invasion of my space. I don't want to hear what they are listening to. 
econd, you have to be able to listen to the book at a certain pace.
 I am a pretty fast reader and I can get through a book pretty fast. With an audiobook, I have to listen to the words only as fast as the speaker is dictating them. Also, I can go back and re-read a page or passage much easier in a regular book than I can with an audiobook. I have to rewind and hope I stop at the right point. It's frustrating. Third, I don't like the way audiobooks sound.
 With an audiobook, you have to hope you like the sound of the narrators voice. If you do, you are in good shape, if not, it can make for a long and arduous listen. It also is harder, for me at least, to get a good mental image of the scene while listening to an audiobook. I can see it in my head much easier when I read. 
Finally, I can't lend an audiobook to a friend or family member as easily as a physical book. I have to lend them my phone or tablet, and I don't want to do that. With a physical book. I can just hand them the book and they can give it back when they are done. It gives me the pleas

 I am a pretty fast reader and I can get through a book pretty fast. With an audiobook, I have to listen to the words only as fast as the speaker is dictating them. Also, I can go back and re-read a page or passage much easier in a regular book than I can with an audiobook. I have to rewind and hope I stop at the right point. It's frustrating. Third, I don't like the way audiobooks sound.
 With an audiobook, you have to hope you like the sound of the narrators voice. If you do, you are in good shape, if not, it can make for a long and arduous listen. It also is harder, for me at least, to get a good mental image of the scene while listening to an audiobook. I can see it in my head much easier when I read. 
Finally, I can't lend an audiobook to a friend or family member as easily as a physical book. I have to lend them my phone or tablet, and I don't want to do that. With a physical book. I can just hand them the book and they can give it back when they are done. It gives me the pleasure of knowing I ha

Finally, I can't lend an audiobook to a friend or family member as easily as a physical book. I have to lend them my phone or tablet, and I don't want to do that. With a physical book. I can just hand them the book and they can give it back when they are done. It gives me the pleasure of knowing I have shared something

Is Listening to a Book Just as Good as Reading It?

Do you listen to audiobooks? What are the benefits, in your opinion, of listening instead of reading? Are there advantages to reading that cannot be gained by listening? Which method do you prefer? Why?

---

In my opinion, audiobooks are not as convenient as regular books for multiple reasons. First, to use an audiobook, you have to have speakers or headphones and that can be cumbersome to have with you at all times. I know I find it rude when someone in a waiting room or on public transportation is listening to an audiobook or something on their phone without headphones. It is like an invasion of my space. I don't want to hear what they are listening to. 
econd, you have to be able to listen to the book at a certain pace.
 I am a pretty fast reader and I can get through a book pretty fast. With an audiobook, I have to listen to the words only as fast as the speaker is dictating them. Also, I can go back and re-read a page or passage much easier in a regular book than I can with an audiobook. I have to rewind and hope I stop at the right point. It's frustrating. Third, I don't like the way audiobooks sound.

Finally, I can't lend an audiobook to a friend or family member as easily as a physical book. I have to lend them my phone or tablet, and I don't want to do that. With a physical book. I can just hand them the book and they can give it back when they are done. It gives me the pleasure of knowing I have shared something t

Is Listening to a Book Just as Good as Reading It?

Do you listen to audiobooks? What are the benefits, in your opinion, of listening instead of reading? Are there advantages to reading that cannot be gained by listening? Which method do you prefer? Why?

---

In my opinion, audiobooks are not as convenient as regular books for multiple reasons. First, to use an audiobook, you have to have speakers or headphones and that can be cumbersome to have with you at all times. I know I find it rude when someone in a waiting room or on public transportation is listening to an audiobook or something on their phone without headphones. It is like an invasion of my space. I don't want to hear what they are listening to. 
econd, you have to be able to listen to the book at a certain pace.
 I am a pretty fast reader and I can get through a book pretty fast. With an audiobook, I have to listen to the words only as fast as the speaker is dictating them. Also, I can go back and re-read a page or passage much easier in a regular book than I can with an audiobook. I have to rewind and hope I stop at the right point. It's frustrating. Third, I don't like the way audiobooks sound.
 With an audiobook, you have to hope you like the sound of the narrators voice. If you do, you are in good shape, if not, it can make for a long and arduous listen. It also is harder, for me at least, to get a good mental image of the scene while listening to an audiobook. I can see it in my head much easier when I read. 
Finally, I can't lend an audiobook to a friend or family member as easily as a physical book. I have to lend them my phone or tablet, and I don't want to do that. With a physical book. I can just hand them the book and they can give it back when they are done. It gives me the pleasure of knowing I have shared something that I enjoy with some

Do you listen to audiobooks? What are the benefits, in your opinion, of listening instead of reading? Are there advantages to reading that cannot be gained by listening? Which method do you prefer? Why?

---

In my opinion, audiobooks are not as convenient as regular books for multiple reasons. First, to use an audiobook, you have to have speakers or headphones and that can be cumbersome to have with you at all times. I know I find it rude when someone in a waiting room or on public transportation is listening to an audiobook or something on their phone without headphones. It is like an invasion of my space. I don't want to hear what they are listening to. 
econd, you have to be able to listen to the book at a certain pace.
 I am a pretty fast reader and I can get through a book pretty fast. With an audiobook, I have to listen to the words only as fast as the speaker is dictating them. Also, I can go back and re-read a page or passage much easier in a regular book than I can with an audiobook. I have to rewind and hope I stop at the right point. It's frustrating. Third, I don't like the way audiobooks sound.
 With an audiobook, you have to hope you like the sound of the narrators voice. If you do, you are in good shape, if not, it can make for a long and arduous listen. It also is harder, for me at least, to get a good mental image of the scene while listening to an audiobook. I can see it in my head much easier when I read. 
Finally, I can't lend an audiobook to a friend or family member as easily as a physical book. I have to lend them my phone or tablet, and I don't want to do that. With a physical book. I can just hand them the book and they can give it back when they are done. It gives me the pleasure of knowing I have shared something that I enjoy with someone hoping that th

Do you listen to audiobooks? What are the benefits, in your opinion, of listening instead of reading? Are there advantages to reading that cannot be gained by listening? Which method do you prefer? Why?

---

In my opinion, audiobooks are not as convenient as regular books for multiple reasons. First, to use an audiobook, you have to have speakers or headphones and that can be cumbersome to have with you at all times. I know I find it rude when someone in a waiting room or on public transportation is listening to an audiobook or something on their phone without headphones. It is like an invasion of my space. I don't want to hear what they are listening to. 
econd, you have to be able to listen to the book at a certain pace.
 I am a pretty fast reader and I can get through a book pretty fast. With an audiobook, I have to listen to the words only as fast as the speaker is dictating them. Also, I can go back and re-read a page or passage much easier in a regular book than I can with an audiobook. I have to rewind and hope I stop at the right point. It's frustrating. Third, I don't like the way audiobooks sound.
 With an audiobook, you have to hope you like the sound of the narrators voice. If you do, you are in good shape, if not, it can make for a long and arduous listen. It also is harder, for me at least, to get a good mental image of the scene while listening to an audiobook. I can see it in my head much easier when I read. 
Finally, I can't lend an audiobook to a friend or family member as easily as a physical book. I have to lend them my phone or tablet, and I don't want to do that. With a physical book. I can just hand them the book and they can give it back when they are done. It gives me the pleasure of knowing I have shared something that I enjoy with someone hoping that they will enjoy it as we

It also is harder, for me at least, to get a good mental image of the scene while listening to an audiobook. I can see it in my head much easier when I read. 
Finally, I can't lend an audiobook to a friend or family member as easily as a physical book. I have to lend them my phone or tablet, and I don't want to do that. With a physical book. I can just hand them the book and they can give it back when they are done. It gives me the pleasure of knowing I have shared something that I enjoy with someone hoping that they will enjoy it as well.

Is Listening to a Book Just as Good as Reading It?

Do you listen to audiobooks? What are the benefits, in your opinion, of listening instead of reading? Are there advantages to reading that cannot be gained by listening? Which method do you prefer? Why?

---

In my opinion, audiobooks are not as convenient as regular books for multiple reasons. First, to use an audiobook, you have to have speakers or headphones and that can be cumbersome to have with you at all times. I know I find it rude when someone in a waiting room or on public transportation is listening to an audiobook or something on their phone without headphones. It is like an invasion of my space. I don't want to hear what they are listening to. 
econd, you have to be able to listen to the book at a certain pace.
 I am a pretty fast reader and I can get through a book pretty fast. With an audiobook, I have to listen to the words only as fast as the speaker is dictating them. Also, I can go back and re-read a page or passage much easier in a regular book than I can with an audiobook. I have to rewind and hope I stop at the right point. It's frustrating. Third, I don't like the way audiobooks sound.
 With an audiobook, you have to hope you like the sound of the narrators voice. If you do, you are in good shape, if not, it can make for a long and arduous listen. It also is harder, for me at least, to get a good mental image of the scene while listening to an audiobook. I can see it in my head much easier when I read. 
Finally, I can't lend an audiobook to a friend or family member as easily as a physical book. I have to lend them my phone or tablet, and I don't want to do that. With a physical book. I can just hand them the book and they can give it back when they are done. It gives me the pleasure of knowing I have shared something that I enjoy with someone hoping that they will enjoy it as well. 
I am no

I know I find it rude when someone in a waiting room or on public transportation is listening to an audiobook or something on their phone without headphones. It is like an invasion of my space. I don't want to hear what they are listening to. 
econd, you have to be able to listen to the book at a certain pace.
 I am a pretty fast reader and I can get through a book pretty fast. With an audiobook, I have to listen to the words only as fast as the speaker is dictating them. Also, I can go back and re-read a page or passage much easier in a regular book than I can with an audiobook. I have to rewind and hope I stop at the right point. It's frustrating. Third, I don't like the way audiobooks sound.
 With an audiobook, you have to hope you like the sound of the narrators voice. If you do, you are in good shape, if not, it can make for a long and arduous listen. It also is harder, for me at least, to get a good mental image of the scene while listening to an audiobook. I can see it in my head much easier when I read. 
Finally, I can't lend an audiobook to a friend or family member as easily as a physical book. I have to lend them my phone or tablet, and I don't want to do that. With a physical book. I can just hand them the book and they can give it back when they are done. It gives me the pleasure of knowing I have shared something that I enjoy with someone hoping that they will enjoy it as well. 
I am not saying that there

---

In my opinion, audiobooks are not as convenient as regular books for multiple reasons. First, to use an audiobook, you have to have speakers or headphones and that can be cumbersome to have with you at all times. I know I find it rude when someone in a waiting room or on public transportation is listening to an audiobook or something on their phone without headphones. It is like an invasion of my space. I don't want to hear what they are listening to. 
econd, you have to be able to listen to the book at a certain pace.
 I am a pretty fast reader and I can get through a book pretty fast. With an audiobook, I have to listen to the words only as fast as the speaker is dictating them. Also, I can go back and re-read a page or passage much easier in a regular book than I can with an audiobook. I have to rewind and hope I stop at the right point. It's frustrating. Third, I don't like the way audiobooks sound.
 With an audiobook, you have to hope you like the sound of the narrators voice. If you do, you are in good shape, if not, it can make for a long and arduous listen. It also is harder, for me at least, to get a good mental image of the scene while listening to an audiobook. I can see it in my head much easier when I read. 
Finally, I can't lend an audiobook to a friend or family member as easily as a physical book. I have to lend them my phone or tablet, and I don't want to do that. With a physical book. I can just hand them the book and they can give it back when they are done. It gives me the pleasure of knowing I have shared something that I enjoy with someone hoping that they will enjoy it as well. 
I am not saying that there are no advantages to

It gives me the pleasure of knowing I have shared something that I enjoy with someone hoping that they will enjoy it as well.

Is Listening to a Book Just as Good as Reading It?

Do you listen to audiobooks? What are the benefits, in your opinion, of listening instead of reading? Are there advantages to reading that cannot be gained by listening? Which method do you prefer? Why?

---

In my opinion, audiobooks are not as convenient as regular books for multiple reasons. First, to use an audiobook, you have to have speakers or headphones and that can be cumbersome to have with you at all times. I know I find it rude when someone in a waiting room or on public transportation is listening to an audiobook or something on their phone without headphones. It is like an invasion of my space. I don't want to hear what they are listening to. 
econd, you have to be able to listen to the book at a certain pace.
 I am a pretty fast reader and I can get through a book pretty fast. With an audiobook, I have to listen to the words only as fast as the speaker is dictating them. Also, I can go back and re-read a page or passage much easier in a regular book than I can with an audiobook. I have to rewind and hope I stop at the right point. It's frustrating. Third, I don't like the way audiobooks sound.
 With an audiobook, you have to hope you like the sound of the narrators voice. If you do, you are in good shape, if not, it can make for a long and arduous listen. It also is harder, for me at least, to get a good mental image of the scene while listening to an audiobook. I can see it in my head much easier when I read. 
Finally, I can't lend an audiobook to a friend or family member as easily as a physical book. I have to lend them my phone or tablet, and I don't want to do that. With a physical book. I can just hand them the book and they can give it back when they are done. It gives me the pleasure of knowing I have shared something that I enjoy with someone hoping that they will enjoy it as well. 
I am not saying that there are no advantages to audiobooks, but mo

It gives me the pleasure of knowing I have shared something that I enjoy with someone hoping that they will enjoy it as well. 
I am not saying that there are no advantages to audiobooks, but more why I grea

Is Listening to a Book Just as Good as Reading It?

Do you listen to audiobooks? What are the benefits, in your opinion, of listening instead of reading? Are there advantages to reading that cannot be gained by listening? Which method do you prefer? Why?

---

In my opinion, audiobooks are not as convenient as regular books for multiple reasons. First, to use an audiobook, you have to have speakers or headphones and that can be cumbersome to have with you at all times. I know I find it rude when someone in a waiting room or on public transportation is listening to an audiobook or something on their phone without headphones. It is like an invasion of my space. I don't want to hear what they are listening to. 
econd, you have to be able to listen to the book at a certain pace.
 I am a pretty fast reader and I can get through a book pretty fast. With an audiobook, I have to listen to the words only as fast as the speaker is dictating them. Also, I can go back and re-read a page or passage much easier in a regular book than I can with an audiobook. I have to rewind and hope I stop at the right point. It's frustrating. Third, I don't like the way audiobooks sound.
 With an audiobook, you have to hope you like the sound of the narrators voice. If you do, you are in good shape, if not, it can make for a long and arduous listen. It also is harder, for me at least, to get a good mental image of the scene while listening to an audiobook. I can see it in my head much easier when I read. 
Finally, I can't lend an audiobook to a friend or family member as easily as a physical book. I have to lend them my phone or tablet, and I don't want to do that. With a physical book. I can just hand them the book and they can give it back when they are done. It gives me the pleasure of knowing I have shared something that I enjoy with someone hoping that they will enjoy it as well. 
I am not saying that there are no advantages to audiobooks, but more why I great

It gives me the pleasure of knowing I have shared something that I enjoy with someone hoping that they will enjoy it as well. 
I am not saying that there are no advantages to audiobooks, but more why I greatly prefer physica

Is Listening to a Book Just as Good as Reading It?

Do you listen to audiobooks? What are the benefits, in your opinion, of listening instead of reading? Are there advantages to reading that cannot be gained by listening? Which method do you prefer? Why?

---

In my opinion, audiobooks are not as convenient as regular books for multiple reasons. First, to use an audiobook, you have to have speakers or headphones and that can be cumbersome to have with you at all times. I know I find it rude when someone in a waiting room or on public transportation is listening to an audiobook or something on their phone without headphones. It is like an invasion of my space. I don't want to hear what they are listening to. 
econd, you have to be able to listen to the book at a certain pace.
 I am a pretty fast reader and I can get through a book pretty fast. With an audiobook, I have to listen to the words only as fast as the speaker is dictating them. Also, I can go back and re-read a page or passage much easier in a regular book than I can with an audiobook. I have to rewind and hope I stop at the right point. It's frustrating. Third, I don't like the way audiobooks sound.
 With an audiobook, you have to hope you like the sound of the narrators voice. If you do, you are in good shape, if not, it can make for a long and arduous listen. It also is harder, for me at least, to get a good mental image of the scene while listening to an audiobook. I can see it in my head much easier when I read. 
Finally, I can't lend an audiobook to a friend or family member as easily as a physical book. I have to lend them my phone or tablet, and I don't want to do that. With a physical book. I can just hand them the book and they can give it back when they are done. It gives me the pleasure of knowing I have shared something that I enjoy with someone hoping that they will enjoy it as well. 
I am not saying that there are no advantages to audiobooks, but more why I greatly prefer physical

Finally, I can't lend an audiobook to a friend or family member as easily as a physical book. I have to lend them my phone or tablet, and I don't want to do that. With a physical book. I can just hand them the book and they can give it back when they are done. It gives me the pleasure of knowing I have shared something that I enjoy with someone hoping that they will enjoy it as well. 
I am not saying that there are no advantages to audiobooks, but more why I greatly prefer physical books over an audi

Is Listening to a Book Just as Good as Reading It?

Do you listen to audiobooks? What are the benefits, in your opinion, of listening instead of reading? Are there advantages to reading that cannot be gained by listening? Which method do you prefer? Why?

---

In my opinion, audiobooks are not as convenient as regular books for multiple reasons. First, to use an audiobook, you have to have speakers or headphones and that can be cumbersome to have with you at all times. I know I find it rude when someone in a waiting room or on public transportation is listening to an audiobook or something on their phone without headphones. It is like an invasion of my space. I don't want to hear what they are listening to. 
econd, you have to be able to listen to the book at a certain pace.
 I am a pretty fast reader and I can get through a book pretty fast. With an audiobook, I have to listen to the words only as fast as the speaker is dictating them. Also, I can go back and re-read a page or passage much easier in a regular book than I can with an audiobook. I have to rewind and hope I stop at the right point. It's frustrating. Third, I don't like the way audiobooks sound.
 With an audiobook, you have to hope you like the sound of the narrators voice. If you do, you are in good shape, if not, it can make for a long and arduous listen. It also is harder, for me at least, to get a good mental image of the scene while listening to an audiobook. I can see it in my head much easier when I read. 
Finally, I can't lend an audiobook to a friend or family member as easily as a physical book. I have to lend them my phone or tablet, and I don't want to do that. With a physical book. I can just hand them the book and they can give it back when they are done. It gives me the pleasure of knowing I have shared something that I enjoy with someone hoping that they will enjoy it as well. 
I am not saying that there are no advantages to audiobooks, but more why I greatly prefer physical books over an audio
